last_replies.com:
paranoia is a hell of a thing. even if you know rationally that something should be so, and that the alternative is extremely unlikely, your emotions just keep on worrying. it's unique because, normally if something is irrational, it stops being serious; yes you might still feel things, but it's not a big deal. when you're paranoid, it doesn't stop being serious, and body doesn't stop feeling like a possibility, even when you know it should be irrational. Even your mind gets led by the possibility.

he should know better than to compare you to an ex, but he's probably just being paranoid that you are unfaithful. Paranoia is no pushover, it's defining feature is that it doesn't go away just because what you said made sense. Funny enough, my lover has trust issues that I am now trying to heal, and even I just so happened to have something I felt paranoid about very recently, so I know what it's like personally, and it is relevant to what i'm working on.

Right now, he is probably being led around by his emotions. You will probably want to let him know the situation; ya know, that you actually sincerely do not want to betray him or be some whore.


these are the 3 points where I actually conquered my paranoia.
1: isn't it much simpler and more likely to think that things really are just the way they seem?
2: you are probably hurting and accusing an innocent person, saying such things.
This was enough to conquer the emotional side

Immediately after, I started going full swing on the rational issue, so I could be totally certain it wasn't a possibility. I found both solutions in the same moment, so it's the 3rd point.
1: it is not unreasonable for you to just have a little faith, despite the possibility, as that is for most people how they do it. In fact it is a proper, and practically an essential thing that you should have some faith. This was the weaker reason.
2: I found a solution that avoids the worst conclusion, even if I was wrong. This was the stronger reason.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>27810243
Depends on a lot of factors. Why are you only doing half an hour, do you not have a lot of time? Are you not fit enough to do longer exercise? Do you do super intense exercise for a shorter period rather than slower-paced workouts for longer? Are you doing 30 minutes daily, or only a few days a week like you'd pace a more intensive workout? You likely could and possibly should be doing more, but especially if you're only just starting, 30 minutes is perfectly fine. If you push yourself too far out of your comfort zone based on what idiots on 4chan tell you, you could get hurt. Push yourself a little bit further than you think you could go every day, but take care of yourself anon.

I think that while I always believed an academic career would make me happiest, I think it might make me miserable if I crashed and burned, and I wouldn't dislike a more cushy office job. I always knew my weaknesses, but I didn't realise how much I noticeably struggled until I got the results. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: College isn't going horrible for me but I have some high stakes right now. I got an academic suspension because of some GPA bullshit and I fought to get off it before this semester. Im doing fine this semester as I have a B and A in two of my IT classes but a D in my math class. The high stakes come in the fact that if I don't pass with a B or above (I think) I could be back on suspension. It was a whole pain in the ass to get back into college. I don't know how to really "study" hard y'know? Especially math since every website or course classifies intermediate algebra under different things. I have a fine retail day job that pays decent if I were to drop out. The problem is that im the only "good" kid on my mom's side. My brother is in jail, my cousin had three kids on accident and has no job and my younger cousin is a roastie who is going in a downward spiral. I feel pressured into becoming a successful adult. What should I do?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27809064
this is going to come off without any structure because it's advice from all over the place

first of all, good job buddy. youve done ridiculously well for yourself in spite of all the negative things you've mentioned in your life.
now, detach yourself from the outcome, and focus on the effort.
it doesnt matter even if you fail out, you can still do many things to become a successful adult. success never eludes the persistent
think of the number of truly mediocre people who passed with their college degrees. but that's more outcome dependency
this isn't something you should so easily accept, especially if you have goals for yourself

now paradoxically, focusing on effort and not outcome, you still need that positive vision in your head of what it means to have made it, because that vision is the potential of you, and to have it will pull you through the hardest times

you're just coming up with a lame excuse for why the math learning is going to be difficult, and rationalising away your potential by accepting your current situation.
you know better than that, but the idea is not to get hung up on it. it's to let it inspire you to want it enough

a college degree, a good job, a stable future. an easier death. take the philosophy as far as you need to do realise that you are just 2 hours a day away from success.

>focus on your goal to inspire yourself
>use that inspiration to push your best effort forward instead of aiming for arbitrary labels
>reaffirm yourself with positive ideation to counter the human condition of anxiety and quitting

last_replies.com:
>>27809064
I advise you as someone who dropped out of college (for similar reasons) to keep going, otherwise you will (for a good reason)regret it. I got the degree afterall but it was not worth making a big deal out of it. In the end no one cares. You will probably earn more money but that's for the short term. Many ways to help you.

The real issue is how you maybe approach math
Studying hard is the wrong approach, instead study less but in short sprints, every day a bit. Learn where your knowledge could be improved, the source matters only as far as it is reliable.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27809225
I had a bunch of days of just laying in my bed with nothing except just wanting peace. I don’t think that has to be bad to do sometimes. But you don’t want to eventually spring up and pick right back up where you started. And you also don’t want to cultivate brooding, toxic emotions.

One of the great human problems is how insanely hard it is for us to ever take anything seriously, unless it is an acute threat, or a traumatic experience that forces us. I think it’s important to understand that when I talk about seriousness, I’m really talking about a depth and clarity, and a willingness. It’s not just another emotion that you ride hard, it’s a quality that comes from clarity… From seeing just how bad the situation really is. Decades of trying with zero results. From seeing that you have genuinely never gotten away with anything. We don’t like things to be serious, so we hide from it, and distract ourselves from it and numb ourselves. And then we never change. I think true human maturity is when you can find this seriousness, and have your life and soul on the line, while simultaneously things feeling light and relaxed. There’s a radical willingness behind all of that. The only way you can do what you need to do, and sustain it for as long as you need to, is if you learn to relax while being present with the stuff you want to avoid. And this is the key. Relaxing doesn’t mean you make it feel any different. It means accepting it as it is, without stoking the fire nor repressing it. For example, you can be filled with anger, while sort of relaxing behind it. The way anger controls you is because it burns, and by thinking the thoughts and doing the things you do when you’re angry, you get some kind of minor relief. But you can also just voluntarily explore that burning sensation, and be willing to experience it. Because you’ve understood that you have no choice. You gain an enormous freedom from that, you grow up from it

My girlfriend is constantly asking for me to spend time with her on the weekends, which includes preplanning things weeks in advance. I'm quite a slow person, and I also enjoy spending time on my own on the weekends to run errands and catch up with personal projects, however a lot of my friends seem to require a lot of attention and I feel like I'm spreading myself a little too thin. I'm 26 years old and I'm not sure what the expected amount of time I should be spending with friends and family is.

I feel like I'm not spending enough time with personal development in my life and I was wondering if any of you could shed a little light on what's expected for the average person my age to commit to social aspects of their life? Is there a number of friends I shouldn't overextend on? A lot of my peers seem to be desperate to be social, I don't like saying no, yet I prefer spending the majority of my time on my own otherwise I feel like I'm falling behind intelectually. I get quite drained spending time around others and I almost feel selfish for telling other I don't want to be around them, so I can spend some time with myself. I feel like now is a vital time in my career to learn and maybe I'm missing out by spending too much time with friends.

>My fear is that i would get rejected
just how bad do you think that is?
like concretely, what's the absolute worst outcome that could possibly happen?
like, if you actually tell them the nature of how you feel: sad, empty, hopeless, whatever.
what's the worst possible outcome?

what sort of outcome do you think would be reasonable to expect, if the other person cared about you?

i think that what the other anon was going on about with just burying your emotions is a poor coping strategy built around avoidance. it necessarily promotes anxiety, because anything that reminds you of how you "really are" makes you feel like shit. so you disengage from reality to try and prevent thinking about the bad feelings, instead of dealing with the fucking core problem to begin with.

you might already be in that trap and therefore not in a position to logically work your way through it, and you might have to use a strategy like burying your emotions.

you're struggling to cope with loss. your self worth is eroded because you had a good thing, and now that good thing is gone, and it feels like it's your fault.
and it's not like it's a bad thing to analyze yourself to try and discover problems with how you did things, but it is a bad thing when you grind your self-worth into the dirt by blaming yourself entirely for every bad thing that happens in your life.

relationships fail, a lot. you are going to fail a lot. and there is stuff you can do better, you're not perfect, but a lot of shit is just because of chance. you're disappointed in yourself for not meeting some standard you've created in your mind. you self sabotage as a way of punishment, and as a way of avoiding potential future failures.
it's guilt, it's loss, it's self esteem.
it's going to take work to get out of it, but this intense self analysis is not helpful for you long term.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Been having panic attacks recently during courses at uni. It just started out of nowhere, but I guess I have been stressed for a while and I was just pushed right over the edge. What should I do? I've tried breathing exercises and thinking about other things, but so far nothing has helped. Doctors are also very hesitant to give you anything in my country, so I feel like I can't do anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27808753
Box breathing (5 seconds in, hold for 5, 5 out, hold for 5, repeat) will eventual stop a panic attack if you do it long enough. It is biology. Your body's fight or flight response is triggered by shallow breathing which builds up too much oxygen in your blood. Box breathing returns the carbon dioxide in your blood to normal which activates your parasympathetic nervous system. An actual good doctor explained this to me and I've never had a panic attack where this didn't eventually work, it is just obviously unpleasant while it is happening. You should do it throughout the day or when you start to feel nervous, ideally lying down with your feet elevated above your heart.
